comment.author: 60329026@N07
comment._content:
Might I suggest a slight alteration to the caption of the photo 
Slag is the by product of smelting metal, the correct term should be 
tailings, spoil, mine dumps, slimes, tails, refuse, or slickens
Take your pick. 
Initially I doubted it was in the Avoca Valley as the spoil was too light in tone, most of the mining waste has a redish hue to it which would have been a much darker shade of grey in the photo, but Niall' s Bing Maps shows this spoil heap to be very light in colour.
The mine buildings which you refer to with the chimneys were boiler & pump houses which were used to pump water out of the workings below ground.

Have a look at this image which was taken up the track and looking towards those chimneys www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009/4014192965/

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/60329026@N07] In Scotland a heap of mine waste is called a Bing, an unfortunate choice of name for a search engine. They were mining for copper. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avoca,_County_Wicklow

comment.author: 34574252@N02
comment._content:
Avoca mines consisted of East Avoca, West Avoca and Cronebane all for mining copper [very, very small amounts of gold etc were found].

Both underground mining and opencast mining was in operation and the buildings were a mixture of pumping houses for the underground shafts and for crushing machinery. 

What we see in the photograph is possibility a mixture of the opencast mining and spoil heaps. 

The building and chimney top right would be the 'Williams Engine House' part of which survives - the Williams shaft is capped.

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content: The Geological Survey of Ireland have a little booklet on mining in Avoca which you can get for a few euros. To briefly summarise: - 1720: First recorded mine production began. Copper, some silver, some gold. Iron had been mined for centuries. - 1791: Act of Parliament incorporates Associated Irish Mine company. Extracted copper, and employed up to 2000 people. Manager was Thomas Weaver. - 1798: Two mine managers were rewarded for their "spirited and judicious conduct" in dealing with insurgents during rebellion. - 1811: Williams Brothers (Cornwall) acquired mine (see Williams Shaft Engine House marked) until 1884. - 1840 - 1880: pyrite also mined for sulfur (a very unpleasant process). During 19th century, technological innovations included steam to power water pumps (it would have been a horse going in a circle before this), a tramway to transport ores to Arklow (for Swansea). - 1880: Large scale mining ceased. - 1956: Mianraí Teoranta explored potential for sulfur and copper mining. Mogul International (Canada) bought mines, trading as St Patrick's Copper mines Ltd. Closed 1962. (An ore carrier was lost off the Irish coast) - 1969 - 1982: 8 million tonnes of ore extracted by Discovery Mines (Canada) trading as Avoca Mines Ltd. The underground workings were flooded in 1982. There's lots more in the booklet and lots of pictures too! Well worth €2.50 :)

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content:
Alfred Webb (NLI: P 358(2)), who walked through Wicklow over three days in 1851 wrote of a visit to these mines. I've bolded the important bits for those who like to scan (like me!):
Dinner over, we proceeded to the Cronebane copper mines, on the east bank of the Avoca. These mines give a great deal of employment to the surrounding population. Although called copper mines, their principal produce is sulphur, as the 4 ½ per cent of copper which the ore yielded, was found scarcely to pay the cost of working; consequently, a number of large waterwheels up the face of the hill, which were used for crushing the copper ore, are now lying useless. We crossed the river and went up the hill, to look at a water-wheel employed for drawing wagons out of a shaft. At the invitation of one of the miners we went part of the way down the shaft, and found the air quite cold, and heavy with the fumes of sulphur and gunpowder. We then ascended to the top of the hill to obtain some good specimens of copper ore, and had a good view of the works at the Ballymurtague mines on the opposite side of the river. The water about the mines is so highly impregnated with copper, that in its passage down the face of the hill in spouts, half filled with old pieces of iron, it deposits the copper on the iron in great quantities, amounting to tons in the course of the year. Having obtained the desired specimens, and given the miner, who had accompanied us, something for his trouble, we descended, and examined an undershot water-wheel, turned by one of the tributaries of the Avoca, and serving to pump water out of the mines by a series of cranks about half-a-mile long.

comment._content: Slag heaps I know about! Grew up in a mining town. Left over melted rock after you extract the mineral you want. They use them here to pave roads with, but mostly just leave them in piles as they have in the photo. What kind of mine is this? Wikipedia seems to show copper mines in the area; we also had these where I grew up. Nickel/copper actually. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inco_Superstack

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] 
I was staying in Knockanree Lower over the weekend and I was given a book dated 1912 entitled 'Avoca - A History of the Vale' by Rev. P Dempsey C.C. of the parish of Redcross. In it he states (I do hope you don't mine me writing it in full :) :
"The name of the village has recently been changed from Newbridge to Avoca, and the latter spelling, instead of 'Ovoca', universally adopted. For this alteration the author of the present work may claim some personal credit, as it was on his own initiative that public attention was first drawn to the desirability of restoring to the village its historic designation and of securing at the same time the fullest popular and official recognition for the correct form of the name."
On a finger post in Conary the Irish for Avoca is Abhainn Mhor - the big river? The distances are still in miles :). [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03/7582927000/]

comment.author: 58324776@N05
comment._content:
I can't add much to the above except to say that this a view of the Tigroney mines taken from Ballymurtagh.
The house in the foreground is Avoca House - long since gone. Directly above that is 'River Lodge' formerly the mine manager's residence. The outbuildings are all derelict now, but the principal building survives and is currently lived in.
The topmost cottage no longer exists.

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 93810272@N05
comment._content: Williams' engine house on the far right accommodated a 60-inch vertical high pressure steam engine manufactured in the late 1850s by the Perran Foundry, Cornwall. Baronet's engine house above and to the left, also contained a Cornish steam engine. The Tigroney sett (and also Cronebane) was worked by the Williams of Scorrier, a Cornish mining dynasty, who also had an interest in the Perran Foundry, from 1833 until about 1872. For interest, the Williams' engine house accommodated the largest Cornish steam engine in all of Ireland. It's conservation is a matter of urgency imho.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
